instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message: Hi Guys/Gals, I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that is getting 19.91V On ampMeter and 1.2 amps at start up...it has No Video either on Display Or External Display...You can hear the iPhone Charging bling whenever you plug in the Charger but No Video...Also the caps Lock light comes on when fans are spinning...<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present (3.3v) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is also present (12.7V) 2 caps had corrosion <CAPACITOR>C7601</CAPACITOR>, and <CAPACITOR>C7664</CAPACITOR>..Both Were Removed and replaced from a identical Donor board...Any suggestions on Where to start....Thank You in Advance...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message:
Does the Caps Lock LED react?
Also check USB activity.
You can try new BIOS file.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message: Hi 2informaticos, And Thank You SO Much for the response...Yes the caps Lock Led does respond to being Pressed (Light goes on and off When Pressed)...There is No USB Activity as I tried with a USB Mouse and also Tried a USB Keyboard for a PRAM reset but no go...ANY help is GREATLY Appreciated :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message:
Board is runing, if you get Caps Lock reaction.
No USB activity and no internal/external video at same time, is very strange in this case.
All USB ports the same?
Check them all for activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message: All USB ports Give the same Values with the USB-C AmpMeter Plugged into them...Fans Spin with each USB port Plugged in...and Caps Lock Responds with each one also

threads.message: Are there any Particular Lines I can Check?...Sorry...These Boards are CRAZY with all these USB Controller Chips!!!...LOL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message:
Did you checked all your S0 rails ? If you have <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> normaly it should be OK.
Is your CPU over heating ? 
Plus you can hear the charging boing this is weird....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message: Have Not checked S0 Rails Yet...CPU is Pretty Hot when fans are spinning...And Yes I can hear the Boing when the USB-C Is plugged into the Machine. Even when the fans are spinning while on Battery and the charger gets plugged in Machine makes the Boing Sound...Which S0 Rails should I check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, any other voltage on this other board?
Check tge basic things and post correct information.
You may want to say 11mA, 0.11A, or 0.061A, no idea really; but impossible to get 10-69A for sure...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message: For sure ! Your board would already be fried , and you with it..... Not possible as your charger is providing something like 4.3A max if it's ? 87W charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message: Yes...Sorry...I Meant its reading 19.89V and just keeps going from 10mA - 61mA on USB-C Meter

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with No Chime Or Display But Fans Spin
threads.message:
You should post basic power on signals.
We need some info to help.
Check if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 are stable.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reaction triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, etc...
Also try starting in SMC bypass mode.
